Package uk.ac.ed.inf.aqmaps.map

Class TourPlanner

java.lang.Object
uk.ac.ed.inf.aqmaps.map.TourPlanner
public class TourPlanner
extends java.lang.Object
The TourPlanner class solves the Travelling Salesman Problem that is induced by a list of sensors that needs to be visited in an order that is as efficient as possible.

  • Constructor Details

    • TourPlanner

      public TourPlanner​(java.util.List<com.mapbox.geojson.Point> points)
      The constructor of the TourPlanner class. I decided to initialise a TourPlanner instance for a list of nodes to be "sorted", and view the distance matrix that defines the problem as an attribute of the planner, as opposed to e.g. using a static approach.
      Parameters:
      points - the list of points that leads to the Travelling Salesman Problem

  • Method Details

    • findShortestTour

      public int[] findShortestTour()
      This method computes the order in which the list of points described by the distance matrix of this object shall be visited by our drone. The last point in the given input list is assumed to be the starting/landing point of the drone, and ultimately removed. That is because it is simply not needed in our scenario - our drone will know when to return to its starting point. Note: Admittedly, the name is slightly misleading, because a shorter tour may exist. But since this is the shortest tour that our algorithm finds, I deemed this name to be appropriate nevertheless.
      Returns:
      the array of indices that defines the tour across the nodes that is deemed shortest

    • computeDistanceMatrix

      private int[][] computeDistanceMatrix​(java.util.List<com.mapbox.geojson.Point> points)
      An instance of the Travelling Salesman Problem can be identified by its distance matrix. This method computes that matrix by simulating how long it will take our main drone to get from each node i to each node j, pairwise.
      Parameters:
      points - the initial list of nodes, where the last point is assumed to be the start/end point of the tour
      Returns:
      the distance matrix for the Travelling Salesman Problem we are facing

    • applyTwoOptAlgorithm

      private void applyTwoOptAlgorithm()
      This method applies the 2-opt algorithm to our tour. This algorithm was chosen because it is rather simple, yields decent results and is very fast (compared to more complex algorithms, such as Lin-Kernighan). We consider each pair of indices and see if reverting the path between the two nodes yields a better cost overall. We stop as soon as no reversion improves the tour cost.

    • tryReverse

      private boolean tryReverse​(int i, int j)
      This method considers the effect of reversing the segment between the points of our tour that currently have index i and j. If this lowers the tour cost, commit to the reversal and return true. Otherwise leave the tour unchanged and return false.
      Parameters:
      i - the index at which the attempted reversal starts
      j - the index at which the attempted reversal ends
      Returns:
      whether the reversal leads to a better tour cost
